question.text: Observe the action potential and state the correct events that occur in Phase I and Phase II.

options.text: Phase I: Sodium channels open causing movement of sodium ions from the extracellular fluid to the axoplasm. Phase II: Potassium channels open causing movement of potassium ions from the extracellular fluid to the axoplasm.

Phase I: Sodium channels open causing movement of sodium ions from the extracellular fluid to the axoplasm. Phase II: Potassium channels open causing movement of potassium ions from the axoplasm to the extracellular fluid.

Phase I: Sodium channels open causing movement of sodium ions from the axoplasm to the extracellular fluid. Phase II: Potassium channels open causing movement of potassium ions from the extracellular fluid to the axoplasm.

Phase I: Sodium channels open causing movement of sodium ions from the axoplasm to the extracellular fluid. Phase II: Potassium channels open causing movement of potassium ions from the axoplasm to the extracellular fluid.

solution.text:
Phase I is depolarization. When a stimulus greater than the threshold stimulus is applied at a point in the axon, the sodium channels open causing movement of sodium ions from the extracellular fluid to the axoplasm. Due to this, the membrane potential rises from -70 mV to + 30 mV.

Phase II is repolarization. After depolarization is over, the potassium channels open causing movement of potassium ions from the axoplasm to the extracellular fluid. Due to this, the membrane potential falls from  +30 mV to - 70 mV.
